vision_json.prompt_sent:
Extract ONLY publication metadata from these academic paper pages.

CRITICAL: This data will be sent to 11 external APIs, so format accuracy is essential.

FIELD REQUIREMENTS WITH EXACT FORMATS:

1. **Title**: Clean title for API queries (HIGHEST PRIORITY)
   - Remove line breaks, extra spaces, formatting
   - No HTML tags or special characters  
   - Example: "Effects of Machine Learning on Healthcare Outcomes"

2. **Authors**: API-compatible author list (HIGHEST PRIORITY)
   - Each author as separate string in array
   - Format: "FirstName LastName" or "F. LastName"
   - Clean, no extra punctuation
   - Example: ["John Smith", "M. Johnson", "Sarah Williams"]

3. **DOI**: Standard DOI format for resolution APIs
   - Must start with "10." if present
   - Clean format without URL prefixes
   - Example: "10.1234/journal.2024.001"

4. **Journal**: Clean journal name for database queries
   - Full journal name preferred over abbreviations
   - Remove extra formatting, parentheses
   - Example: "Nature Medicine"

5. **Year**: Numeric format for date filtering
   - 4-digit NUMBER only (not string)
   - Example: 2024

6. **Volume**: Clean number for bibliographic APIs
   - Numbers only, no "Vol." prefix
   - Example: "15"

7. **Issue**: Clean number format
   - Numbers only, no "No." or "Issue" prefix
   - Example: "3"

8. **Pages**: Standard page range for citations
   - Format: "start-end" or single page
   - Example: "123-135" or "45"

9. **PMID**: PubMed ID for medical APIs
   - Numbers only, no "PMID:" prefix
   - Example: "12345678"

10. **PMCID**: PubMed Central ID for open access papers
    - Numbers only, no "PMC" prefix
    - Often appears near PMID in biomedical papers
    - Example: "9876543"

11. **Keywords**: API-compatible keyword list
    - Each keyword as separate string
    - Research-quality terms, no punctuation
    - Example: ["machine learning", "healthcare", "clinical outcomes"]

11. **Abstract**: Complete clean text (HIGHEST PRIORITY)
    - Remove formatting, line breaks, extra spaces
    - Complete sentences, proper punctuation
    - Search thoroughly across ALL pages
    - This is CRITICAL for Semantic Scholar and other APIs

12. **Publisher**: Clean organization name
    - Official publisher name
    - Example: "Elsevier" or "Nature Publishing Group"

ABSTRACT EXTRACTION PRIORITY:
- Look thoroughly across ALL pages for abstract sections
- Extract COMPLETE text, including multiple paragraphs
- Check: Abstract, Summary, Introduction summary paragraphs
- This field is CRITICAL for API enrichment success

Return JSON format:
{
  "Title": "clean title without formatting",
  "Authors": ["Author One", "Author Two"],
  "DOI": "10.xxxx/xxxxx",
  "Journal": "clean journal name", 
  "Year": 2024,
  "Volume": "15",
  "Issue": "3", 
  "Pages": "123-135",
  "Abstract": "complete clean abstract text",
  "Keywords": ["keyword1", "keyword2"],
  "PMID": "12345678",
  "PMCID": "9876543",
  "Publisher": "publisher name"
}

Return null for fields not clearly visible. The Abstract field is MOST IMPORTANT for downstream API success.

extracted_data.Title: Feasibility and acceptability of the HOLOBalance telerehabilitation system compared with standard care for older adults at risk of falls: the HOLOBalance assessor blinded pilot randomised controlled study
extracted_data.Abstract: Background: Falls have high socioeconomic costs. Information and communication technologies may support provision and monitoring of multisensory (MSR) physiotherapy programmes. The HOLOBalance platform used augmented reality holograms to provide patient-centred, individualised MSR. Objectives: To determine the platform’s safety, acceptability and feasibility, investigate functional gait and dynamic balance benefits and provide data for a definitive trial. Design and setting: Single-blinded pilot randomised controlled feasibility study. Interventions were conducted at clinical sites or participants’ homes in three European countries. Participants: Community-dwelling older adults (median age 73 years; 64.2% female) at risk of falls were enrolled (May 2020-August 2021). Methods: Participants were randomised to an 8-week clinic or home-based telerehabilitation MSR or OTAGO (control group) programme. Compliance, satisfaction, and adverse events determined feasibility. Clinical outcomes, assessed (blinded) within one-week prior to and post-intervention, included functional gait assessment (FGA), Mini BESTest and cognitive function. Results: Randomisation to completion rate was 76.15% with 109 participants recruited (n = 289 screened). Drop-out rate was similar between groups. Adverse events were reported (n = 3) in the control group. Sixty-nine percent would recommend the HOLOBalance intervention. Findings were similar for the home and clinic-based arms of each intervention; data was combined for analysis. FGA (95%CI [1.63, 4.19]) and Mini-BESTest (95%CI [1.46, 3.93]) showed greater improvement in the HOLOBalance group with a clinically meaningful change of 4/30 noted for the FGA. Conclusions: HOLOBalance was feasible to implement and acceptable to older adults at risk of falls, with FGA and Mini-BEST improvements exceeding those for the OTAGO programme. A definitive trial is warranted.

data.title: Feasibility and acceptability of the HOLObalance telerehabilitation system compared with standard care for older adults at risk of falls: the HOLOBalance assessor blinded pilot randomised controlled study
data.abstract:
Background:

Falls have high socioeconomic costs. Information and communication technologies may support provision and monitoring of multisensory (MSR) physiotherapy programmes. The HOLOBalance platform used augmented reality holograms to provide patient-centred, individualised MSR.



Objectives:

To determine the platform’s safety, acceptability and feasibility, investigate functional gait and dynamic balance benefits and provide data for a definitive trial.



Design and setting:

Single-blinded pilot randomised controlled feasibility study. Interventions were conducted at clinical sites or participants’ homes in three European countries.



Participants:

Community-dwelling older adults (median age 73 years; 64.2% female) at risk of falls were enrolled (May 2020-August 2021).



Methods:

Participants were randomised to an 8-week clinic or home-based telerehabilitation MSR or OTAGO (control group) programme. Compliance, satisfaction, and adverse events determined feasibility. Clinical outcomes, assessed (blinded) within one-week prior to and post-intervention, included functional gait assessment (FGA), Mini BESTest and cognitive function.



Results:

Randomisation to completion rate was 76.15% with 109 participants recruited (n = 289 screened). Drop-out rate was similar between groups. Adverse events were reported (n = 3) in the control group. Sixty-nine percent would recommend the HOLOBalance intervention. Findings were similar for the home and clinic-based arms of each intervention; data was combined for analysis. FGA (95%CI [1.63, 4.19]) and Mini-BESTest (95%CI [1.46, 3.93]) showed greater improvement in the HOLOBalance group with a clinically meaningful change of 4/30 noted for the FGA.



Conclusions:

HOLObalance was feasible to implement and acceptable to older adults at risk of falls, with FGA and Mini-BEST improvements exceeding those for the OTAGO programme. A definitive trial is warranted

AbstractText: Falls have high socioeconomic costs. Information and communication technologies may support provision and monitoring of multisensory (MSR) physiotherapy programmes. The HOLOBalance platform used augmented reality holograms to provide patient-centred, individualised MSR.
To determine the platform's safety, acceptability and feasibility, investigate functional gait and dynamic balance benefits and provide data for a definitive trial.
Single-blinded pilot randomised controlled feasibility study. Interventions were conducted at clinical sites or participants' homes in three European countries.
Community-dwelling older adults (median age 73 years; 64.2% female) at risk of falls were enrolled (May 2020-August 2021).

Participants were randomised to an 8-week clinic or home-based telerehabilitation MSR or OTAGO (control group) programme. Compliance, satisfaction, and adverse events determined feasibility. Clinical outcomes, assessed (blinded) within one-week prior to and post-intervention, included functional gait assessment (FGA), Mini BESTest and cognitive function.

Randomisation to completion rate was 76.15% with 109 participants recruited (n = 289 screened). Drop-out rate was similar between groups. Adverse events were reported (n = 3) in the control group. Sixty-nine percent would recommend the HOLOBalance intervention. Findings were similar for the home and clinic-based arms of each intervention; data was combined for analysis. FGA (95%CI [1.63, 4.19]) and Mini-BESTest (95%CI [1.46, 3.93]) showed greater improvement in the HOLOBalance group with a clinically meaningful change of 4/30 noted for the FGA.
HOLObalance was feasible to implement and acceptable to older adults at risk of falls, with FGA and Mini-BEST improvements exceeding those for the OTAGO programme. A definitive trial is warranted.

data.affiliation: Centre for Human and Applied Physiological Sciences, King's College London, London, UK.
data.abstractText:
Background

Falls have high socioeconomic costs. Information and communication technologies may support provision and monitoring of multisensory (MSR) physiotherapy programmes. The HOLOBalance platform used augmented reality holograms to provide patient-centred, individualised MSR.

Objectives

To determine the platform's safety, acceptability and feasibility, investigate functional gait and dynamic balance benefits and provide data for a definitive trial.

Design and setting

Single-blinded pilot randomised controlled feasibility study. Interventions were conducted at clinical sites or participants' homes in three European countries.

Participants

Community-dwelling older adults (median age 73 years; 64.2% female) at risk of falls were enrolled (May 2020-August 2021).

Methods

Participants were randomised to an 8-week clinic or home-based telerehabilitation MSR or OTAGO (control group) programme. Compliance, satisfaction, and adverse events determined feasibility. Clinical outcomes, assessed (blinded) within one-week prior to and post-intervention, included functional gait assessment (FGA), Mini BESTest and cognitive function.

Results

Randomisation to completion rate was 76.15% with 109 participants recruited (n = 289 screened). Drop-out rate was similar between groups. Adverse events were reported (n = 3) in the control group. Sixty-nine percent would recommend the HOLOBalance intervention. Findings were similar for the home and clinic-based arms of each intervention; data was combined for analysis. FGA (95%CI [1.63, 4.19]) and Mini-BESTest (95%CI [1.46, 3.93]) showed greater improvement in the HOLOBalance group with a clinically meaningful change of 4/30 noted for the FGA.

Conclusions

HOLObalance was feasible to implement and acceptable to older adults at risk of falls, with FGA and Mini-BEST improvements exceeding those for the OTAGO programme. A definitive trial is warranted.
data.authorString: Pavlou M, Flavell CA, Gourtani FM, Nikitas C, Kikidis D, Bibas A, Gatsios D, Tsakanikas V, Fotiadis DI, Koutsouris D, Steinicke F, Walz ID, Maurer C, Papadopoulou S, Tsoukatos M, Pardalis A, Bamiou DE.

data.title: Feasibility and acceptability of the HOLObalance telerehabilitation system compared with standard care for older adults at risk of falls: the HOLOBalance assessor blinded pilot randomised controlled study
data.abstract: Abstract Background Falls have high socioeconomic costs. Information and communication technologies may support provision and monitoring of multisensory (MSR) physiotherapy programmes. The HOLOBalance platform used augmented reality holograms to provide patient-centred, individualised MSR. Objectives To determine the platform’s safety, acceptability and feasibility, investigate functional gait and dynamic balance benefits and provide data for a definitive trial. Design and setting Single-blinded pilot randomised controlled feasibility study. Interventions were conducted at clinical sites or participants’ homes in three European countries. Participants Community-dwelling older adults (median age 73 years; 64.2% female) at risk of falls were enrolled (May 2020-August 2021). Methods Participants were randomised to an 8-week clinic or home-based telerehabilitation MSR or OTAGO (control group) programme. Compliance, satisfaction, and adverse events determined feasibility. Clinical outcomes, assessed (blinded) within one-week prior to and post-intervention, included functional gait assessment (FGA), Mini BESTest and cognitive function. Results Randomisation to completion rate was 76.15% with 109 participants recruited (n = 289 screened). Drop-out rate was similar between groups. Adverse events were reported (n = 3) in the control group. Sixty-nine percent would recommend the HOLOBalance intervention. Findings were similar for the home and clinic-based arms of each intervention; data was combined for analysis. FGA (95%CI [1.63, 4.19]) and Mini-BESTest (95%CI [1.46, 3.93]) showed greater improvement in the HOLOBalance group with a clinically meaningful change of 4/30 noted for the FGA. Conclusions HOLObalance was feasible to implement and acceptable to older adults at risk of falls, with FGA and Mini-BEST improvements exceeding those for the OTAGO programme. A definitive trial is warranted.

consensus_result.Title: Feasibility and acceptability of the HOLOBalance telerehabilitation system compared with standard care for older adults at risk of falls: the HOLOBalance assessor blinded pilot randomised controlled study
consensus_result.Abstract: Background: Falls have high socioeconomic costs. Information and communication technologies may support provision and monitoring of multisensory (MSR) physiotherapy programmes. The HOLOBalance platform used augmented reality holograms to provide patient-centred, individualised MSR. Objectives: To determine the platform's safety, acceptability and feasibility, investigate functional gait and dynamic balance benefits and provide data for a definitive trial. Design and setting: Single-blinded pilot randomised controlled feasibility study. Interventions were conducted at clinical sites or participants' homes in three European countries. Participants: Community-dwelling older adults (median age 73 years; 64.2% female) at risk of falls were enrolled (May 2020-August 2021). Methods: Participants were randomised to an 8-week clinic or home-based telerehabilitation MSR or OTAGO (control group) programme. Compliance, satisfaction, and adverse events determined feasibility. Clinical outcomes, assessed (blinded) within one-week prior to and post-intervention, included functional gait assessment (FGA), Mini BESTest and cognitive function. Results: Randomisation to completion rate was 76.15% with 109 participants recruited (n = 289 screened). Drop-out rate was similar between groups. Adverse events were reported (n = 3) in the control group. Sixty-nine percent would recommend the HOLOBalance intervention. Findings were similar for the home and clinic-based arms of each intervention; data was combined for analysis. FGA (95%CI [1.63, 4.19]) and Mini-BESTest (95%CI [1.46, 3.93]) showed greater improvement in the HOLOBalance group with a clinically meaningful change of 4/30 noted for the FGA. Conclusions: HOLOBalance was feasible to implement and acceptable to older adults at risk of falls, with FGA and Mini-BEST improvements exceeding those for the OTAGO programme. A definitive trial is warranted.

confidence_factors.reasoning: Vision data used as foundation with strong API validation from multiple sources. Enhanced with PMID, PMCID, citation count, and open access status from coherent API sources. Author list formatting improved using Crossref/EuropePMC data while maintaining original order.

api_success_summary.insights: Strong coherence among major APIs (Crossref, EuropePMC, PubMed, Semantic Scholar, OpenAlex) validating vision data. Best contributors were EuropePMC and Crossref for detailed metadata. DOAJ failed due to missing DOI, arXiv and DataCite had no matches. Citation data from OpenAlex was preferred over Semantic Scholar due to higher count.

llm_topics_json.prompt_sent:
You are a scientific research assistant extracting data for academic comparison tables with statistical rigor.

CRITICAL INSTRUCTIONS FOR ACADEMIC COMPARISON:

- SYSTEMATICALLY scan ALL content: text, tables, figures, charts, appendices
- PRIORITIZE quantitative data while preserving qualitative context
- When conflicts exist in the paper, prioritize MOST RECENT/AUTHORITATIVE source
- Extract ALL relevant details mentioned - DON'T truncate important information
- Include statistical tests results (Z-scores, t-values, chi-square, etc.)
- Extract accuracy rates, completion rates, success rates with specific numbers
- Capture comparative data (e.g., "46% vs 27%", "Group A: 64.5%, Group B: 68.2%")
- Use proper numeric format: "p = 0.007" not "p = .007", "81" not "eighty-one"

COMPREHENSIVE CAPTURE REQUIREMENTS:

- List ALL hardware components: cameras, sensors, headsets, controllers, phones, tablets, webcams, probes
- Include ALL software details: platforms, SDKs, libraries, export formats (CSV, JSON), feedback systems
- Capture ALL measurement instruments: scales, questionnaires, assessment tools (SUS, NASA-TLX, FES-I, MoCA, IKDC, VAS, ABC scale, WHODAS 2.0, etc.)
- Note ALL technical specifications: resolutions, frame rates, tracking capabilities, joint counts
- Include ALL study phases: pilot tests, technical validation, user studies, expert evaluations
- Capture ALL procedural details: training time, calibration steps, data export processes, real-time feedback

CONFLICT RESOLUTION:

- If conflicting information exists, prioritize methods/results over abstract
- When uncertain, include both: "X in abstract, Y in methods section"

Extract the following 7 scientific topics:

1. *study_design*: Extract the PRIMARY study type/design using the most specific and authoritative terminology from the paper's methods section. Recognize equivalent terms: "RCT" = "Randomized controlled trial", "Pilot study" = "Feasibility pilot study", "Cross-sectional" = "Observational cross-sectional", "User study" = "User evaluation study". When multiple study type descriptions exist, prioritize the most comprehensive version from methods over abstract. Include specific qualifiers when mentioned (e.g., "multicenter", "double-blind", "waitlist-controlled") as these add valuable detail. Format as brief phrase describing core study methodology, avoiding generic terms like "study" or "research" alone.

2. *methodology*: ONE comprehensive sentence covering: technology + application + key technical details. Include: ALL device models, software platforms, measurement tools, statistical analyses. Capture ALL hardware components mentioned (cameras, sensors, controllers, probes, etc.). Include ALL software features (real-time feedback, data export, tracking capabilities). Mention ALL technical specifications (joint tracking numbers, frame rates, resolutions). Example: "Microsoft HoloLens 2 with HoloAnatomy platform for 3D anatomical procedural visualization using real-time motion tracking of 25 joints with CSV data export and real-time visual feedback".

3. *sample_size*: Format: "X participants/patients" (use paper's exact terminology). Include TOTAL numbers if multiple groups exist. Include ALL test phases: technical tests, pilot studies, user evaluations. Example: "25 total: 23 biomedical students + 2 clinical experts; 50 technical validation readings".

4. *population*: ALL demographic details and characteristics not captured in sample_size. Include age, profession, condition, experience, setting details. Add specific numbers when available. Include recruitment sources and inclusion/exclusion criteria.

5. *primary_outcome*: Include ALL measurement tools, scales, timing, specific metrics, usability criteria (ease of use, realism, anatomical accuracy). List ALL assessment instruments used and functional scales (SUS, NASA-TLX, FES-I, MoCA, IKDC, VAS, ABC scale, WHODAS 2.0, etc.), and evaluation dimensions beyond the primary measures.. Include ALL comparison conditions and timepoints. Example: "Patient understanding via 5-point Likert scale assessed pre/post intervention, plus SUS usability scores and NASA-TLX workload assessment".

6. *key_findings*: PRIORITIZE statistical results with practical implications. Format: "Finding 1: [statistical data + meaning]. Finding 2: [data + context]". Include ALL significant findings, p-values, effect sizes, accuracy rates, comparative data, accuracy measurements (sub-mm, degrees), specific understanding domains (surgical risks, operative steps, recovery), and detailed performance metrics beyond statistical significance. Present ALL questionnaire results, prototype performance, qualitative benefits. Include ALL cost factors, training requirements, implementation details. Capture ALL comparison groups and their specific results. Be comprehensive - capture complete findings picture. Include ALL technical specifications mentioned: accuracy measurements (sub-mm, degrees).

7. *limitations*: Extract ALL limitations from limitation/discussion sections. Include sample size issues, technical equipment requirements, methodological, practical constraints. Mention ALL equipment needs, calibration requirements, manufacturing variability. Include ALL generalizability issues, validity concerns, implementation barriers. Capture training requirements, cost constraints, specialized equipment needs. Note real-world applicability issues and clinical implementation challenges. Don't summarize - capture complete limitation landscape.

Return as valid JSON with this EXACT structure:

{
  "study_design": "string",
  "methodology": "string",
  "sample_size": "string",
  "population": "string",
  "primary_outcome": "string",
  "key_findings": "string",
  "limitations": "string"
}

extracted_topics.population: Community-dwelling older adults aged 65-80 at risk of falls, median age 73 years, 64.2% female, recruited from academic clinics in Germany, Greece, and the UK.
extracted_topics.limitations: Sample size limitations, technical issues with sensors and headsets, generalizability concerns due to COVID-19 restrictions, and need for specialised equipment and training.
extracted_topics.methodology: HOLOBalance platform using augmented reality for multisensory rehabilitation with IMU sensors, electronic dashboard for real-time feedback, and data export capabilities.
extracted_topics.key_findings: Finding 1: Randomisation to completion rate was 76.15% with 69% recommending the HOLOBalance system. Finding 2: Greater improvement in FGA (95%CI [1.63, 4.19]) and Mini-BESTest (95%CI [1.46, 3.93]) for HOLOBalance vs OTAGO.
extracted_topics.study_design: Assessor blinded pilot randomised controlled study
extracted_topics.primary_outcome: Functional gait assessment (FGA), Mini BESTest, cognitive function (MoCA), and subjective measures like FES-I and ABC scale assessed pre/post intervention.

```json
{
  "study_design": "Assessor blinded pilot randomised controlled study",
  "methodology": "HOLOBalance platform using augmented reality for multisensory rehabilitation with IMU sensors, electronic dashboard for real-time feedback, and data export capabilities.",
  "sample_size": "109 participants",
  "population": "Community-dwelling older adults aged 65-80 at risk of falls, median age 73 years, 64.2% female, recruited from academic clinics in Germany, Greece, and the UK.",
  "primary_outcome": "Functional gait assessment (FGA), Mini BESTest, cognitive function (MoCA), and subjective measures like FES-I and ABC scale assessed pre/post intervention.",
  "key_findings": "Finding 1: Randomisation to completion rate was 76.15% with 69% recommending the HOLOBalance system. Finding 2: Greater improvement in FGA (95%CI [1.63, 4.19]) and Mini-BESTest (95%CI [1.46, 3.93]) for HOLOBalance vs OTAGO.",
  "limitations": "Sample size limitations, technical issues with sensors and headsets, generalizability concerns due to COVID-19 restrictions, and need for specialised equipment and training."
}
```
